s.text: In any case, in the process of launching U.S. commercial satellites, it is unavoidable that Americans will transfer some technology to the Chinese . To install a satellite, for instance, American engineers work with Chinese engineers to substantially rewire and reprogram the rocket.
Like Russia and the United States, China ripped off its commercial space capabilities from its weapons program.

When the Reagan administration began authorizing commercial space launches in the mid-'80s, American aerospace companies, which typically collaborated on massive government projects, weren't equipped to build entire rockets for commercial use.
Although China currently launches relatively few satellites, Loral, like its competitors Hughes and Lockheed Martin, aims to increase its use of Chinese rockets for several reasons:
In the early '90s, the Chinese launched three to four satellites a year.

In the early '90s, the Chinese launched three to four satellites a year.

And they don't need to--the 13 missiles they supposedly have aimed at the United States have always been judged capable of hitting U.S. cities by the Pentagon (though China's difficulty in commercial launches casts doubt on the Pentagon's assessment).
This shortage forces satellite companies to exploit all available opportunities.
